Dear Ms. Seigo:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on March 29,
2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Modified Settlement Agreement (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is
required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) Agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a minimum,
include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(II) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical examination
shall be completed within 30 calendar days after placement.
Two of eight open foster care files reviewed did not have an initial medical
examination completed within 30 calendar days after placement as required.
File one: The child was removed on 10/20/2021 and there is no documentation
showing the child had an initial medical.
File two: Initial medical exam not completed timely; child was removed on 11/24/21
and initial medical exam completed on 1/11/22.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3/19/2021 Renewal, CAP approved 4/14/2021
4/10/2020 Interim, CAP approved 4/28/2020
R 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not have the Updated Service Plan/Initial
Service Plan completed timely.
File one: USP not completed timely; USP due on 9/6/2021 and was completed on
9/8/2021.
File two: ISP not completed timely; ISP due on 10/22/2021 and was completed on
10/25/2021.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
4

(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child
and the foster parent in the foster parent’s home at least once
every month.
One of eight open foster care files reviewed did not have monthly visitation with the
worker and child in the placement as required.
File one: There is no documented home visit with the child in the placement for the
month of November 2021.
R 400.12422 Foster care record
(3) The record shall contain all of the following information:
(g) A photograph taken at least annually

File one: MISACWIS photo taken on 9/25/2020, case closure on 1/18/2022

(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth
and the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed
and updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.

3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note

FOM 722-03D Placement change
Temporary breaks
The caseworker must update the child's placement in the
placement section of MiSACWIS when the child enters any of the
following temporary breaks:
 AWOLP
 Detention.
 Jail.
 Medical hospitalization.
 Psychiatric hospitalization.

FOM 801-03 Medical passports
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary court
ward.
Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
At or prior to each placement.
Quarterly.
 All medical and mental health professionals to whom the child
is newly referred to and accepted for treatment and/or
services prior to or at the first scheduled appointment while
the foster care case is open, regardless of placement.
Subsequent medical passports are not required.
 Older youth/young adults:
Upon initial independent living placement (youth age 16
and over).
Upon exiting the foster care system (young adults age
18 and older).
Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult:
Within two weeks of re-entry into voluntary foster care.
Upon exiting voluntary foster care.

The screens within MiSACWIS Health Profile section are to be

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
 Reminded the agency to ensure reports are generated and saved.
 PATP’s need to be dated when a signature is obtained.
 Utilize calendar when sending a report back to a worker for corrections to
ensure the corrections are completed timely.
 Document on the signature line of PATP if mailed.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
10

The facility did not request consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period in response to the renewal inspection
completed on 3/19/2021 with a corrective action plan approved on 4/14/2021. During
the review the agency had sixteen violations. Six citations were noted as repeat
violations in the current inspection. During this period under review the agency
expressed the impact that the COVID-19 pandemic had on overall compliance. In
addition, the agency noted that staff turnover and retention impacted overall
compliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency’s difficulty in meeting requirements during this
review period. The Chief Administrator (CA) stated the agency made some
adjustments as a result of the previous year CAP and felt as though it was helpful.
Specifically, the agency is utilizing calendar reminders more frequently as well as a
checklist that was developed. The assessment noted the agency’s struggle with staff
turnover and COVID-19. The assessment also noted the agency’s struggle with
placement crisis which resulted in manpower being focused on other items.
The CA indicated the agency has implemented a foster care task force consisting of
staff and upper management. The task force is aimed at working together to identify
best practices. The CA expressed confidence in the checklist that was developed and
felt as though the agency will improve in several areas.
Interviews
Interviews were conducted with four staff via telephone. Staff acknowledged the past
year has been difficult due to COVID-19. It has been difficult working remote with new
staff. Staff felt as though new staff are not able to learn the job as efficiently as they
could if everyone was in an office setting. In addition, staff noted the struggle related
to staff turnover and difficult cases. However, they noted the hope is there will be
improvements over the current review period. Staff reported feeling supported by
supervisors and reported supervisors are available as needed.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
11

receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
